Triggering Event: She noticed the faded yellow Post-it stuck to her desk calendar, a note she'd written herself months ago: "Doctor's appointment - John." She'd forgotten it was his birthday today.
Generated Assessment: She must have thought I did something terrible if she would've taken such a drastic step as sticking a sticky note to my calendar with a personal message. It's so rude for her to think like that.

Triggering Event: "As she reviewed her patient's chart, she noticed her own signature on a prescription for an experimental drug she'd never heard of. Her stomach churned as she realized she must have been distracted, signing something she shouldn't have. The reminder of her divorce-induced lapse in focus filled her with remorse."
Generated Assessment: "I can't help but feel like she thinks I'm incompetent, maybe even sabotaging patients by adding those extra medications. She might be worried about our conversation earlier, where I mentioned being anxious about starting this new job. It feels like she assumes I'm still struggling to get back into work mode after my last mistake."

Triggering Event: While driving home from a late shift at the hospital, he suddenly realizes he can't recall if he turned off the gas burner in his kitchen that morning. The panic rises like bile in his throat as he pictures his wife asleep upstairs, oblivious to the potential danger. His hands tighten on the steering wheel, knuckles turning white, as he considers turning back but knows it's a 20-minute detour, precious time away from his already worried spouse.
Generated Assessment: **Subjective Reaction** As I drove home, my mind was racing with the what-ifs—what if the gas tank ran out while I was gone, what if the fire alarm went off during my shift, what if someone saw me leave without telling anyone where I was going, what if they thought I abandoned them? Each question fueled another, spiraling into a whirlpool of worst-case scenarios. My heart pounded in my chest, making every breath feel labored. I couldn’t shake the feeling that I was running out of time, that every minute counted. It wasn’t just about getting home; it was about ensuring safety for everyone involved. I could imagine the look of relief on my wife’s face if I got there quickly, but even that thought made my anxiety spike. What if she found out too soon? What if she felt betrayed? The thoughts swirled together, creating an overwhelming sense of dread. I didn’t know how much longer I could hold it together. Every mile felt like a test, each decision a gamble against the unknown. I knew I had to get there, but the road ahead seemed to stretch endlessly, filled with possibilities both good and bad. I just hoped I wouldn’t wake up tomorrow wondering why I hadn’t made it.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

In the staff room, she overhears two colleagues discussing a new teaching method they've started using. They mention how much more engaged and attentive their students are compared to hers. She feels her cheeks flush as she hurriedly leaves the room, clutching her lesson plans tightly.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't help but feel like an idiot for being left out of the conversation. It was clear that everyone else knew what was going on except her. Why did they all get to know about it while she didn't? Wasn't she supposed to be part of the team? Why did they leave her in the dark? The fact that they talked about it so casually made her feel even worse. She felt like she'd missed something important, and now she had no idea what was going on. Her mind raced with thoughts of how she could catch up, but every time she tried to ask questions, she felt like an outsider again. It was like everyone else already shared some secret information that she wasn't privy to. She wished she could just join them, but her face burned with embarrassment whenever she tried to contribute to the conversation. It seemed like everyone else was moving forward smoothly while she lagged behind, feeling more isolated than ever. Even though she tried to keep up, it felt like she was falling further behind, and it was hard not to wonder if she really belonged here.

Triggering Event: The retired chef, his hands trembling slightly, struggled to tie his apron strings. He hadn't worn it in months, but today was different. Today, he was cooking for her. Her favorite dishes, the ones she couldn't eat anymore. The kitchen felt empty without her laughter echoing off the counters. He chopped onions, tears streaming down his face, not from the sting, but from the hopelessness that this would be their last holiday together.
Generated Assessment: She's just being dramatic. We've been over for years now, it's time to move on. I'm not going to get emotional about what could never have been. Life goes on. There's no use dwelling on what we'll never have. It's pointless. She can't cook like me anyway; she's always relied too much on pre-made meals. What did she ever really learn? Cooking is something I took seriously, something I loved, something I excelled at. You can't replace that with some fancy-schmancy new-fangled gadget. Besides, we're old now. People don't live forever. I want to enjoy what little time we have left, not waste it on reminiscing. And besides, there are plenty of other recipes out there. This isn't worth getting worked up over. Let's focus on enjoying what we still have, not constantly looking back. She needs to snap out of this depression nonsense. If anything, this will give us a chance to spend quality time together, bond over our shared love of food. That's all the closure we need. Stop letting your emotions control you. Life moves forward. There’s nothing to be done. It’s time to accept that things will never go back to how they were. So, stop beating yourself up over it. It’s pointless. Just let it go.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She enters her empty apartment, the silence heavier than usual after a long day of teaching apathetic students. The faint scent of leftover coffee lingers in the air, a stark reminder of his absence. She finds a forgotten photograph tucked behind the fridge - them laughing at a picnic years ago. A bitter taste rises in her throat as she tosses it into the trash, but not before tracing their happy faces with a lonely finger.
Generated Assessment: She can't help but feel like she's drowning in the emptiness. Every time she walks through those doors, memories of him flood her mind, making it hard to focus on anything else. It feels like no matter how much she tries to move forward, he's still there, watching over everything he left behind. I'm just trying to get by until I can figure out what's next. I need to keep pushing myself to finish this semester so I can get back home and take care of my family. But every step feels like a burden because I know he'd want me to stay here, to keep fighting for our dreams. He was always the one who pushed me to be better, to never give up. Now that he's gone, I feel lost without someone to believe in me. I guess I'll just have to find another reason to keep going, even if it doesn't feel like enough anymore.

Triggering Event: After weeks of grueling holiday shifts, he wakes up to find his wife has forgotten to set the alarm again. He rushes through his morning routine, spilling coffee grounds on his already-stained uniform. As he kisses her goodbye, she mumbles something about a late night at work, but he barely hears it over the pounding in his temples. Another day of endless lines and impatient customers awaits him, and today, their outdated cash register chooses to malfunction.

Generated Assessment: He sighed inwardly, disappointment settling in his chest like lead. Another cancelled date night. It wasn't the first time this week; she'd changed plans twice already. Maybe tonight wouldn't be different either.

Triggering Event: She found herself standing in their old kitchen, the one she hadn't visited since the divorce. The sunlight filtered through the dusty windows, illuminating the counter where they used to prepare meals together. She noticed a small crack in the tile floor, a imperfection she had never seen before. It was as if the house itself was suffering too, mirroring her own pain. Her heart felt heavy, like the weight of the old memories that still lingered in every corner.

Did he ever think of her? Her thoughts kept drifting back to those moments they shared. The way he held her hand while walking along the beach, the laughter they exchanged during family gatherings, the late-night conversations they had when the world outside seemed quiet. It was as if she was reliving their relationship through her memories, each recollection bringing up more questions than answers. What happened after they stopped talking? She knew that some things were meant to be left alone, yet her curiosity kept pulling her back in. Maybe someday she’d find the strength to move forward, but for now, she just wanted to hold onto these memories. She opened her eyes, letting the light flood in once more. Triggering Event: At 3 AM, Dr. H checked her phone, finding three missed calls from the hospital. The caller ID showed "ER." She tensed, worry immediately gripping her like a vice. Another night of little sleep awaits, she thought as she dialed back, hoping it wasn't another Code Blue.
Generated Assessment: It's no wonder I'm so anxious about my job. My boss always calls me late at night, making me feel like he doesn't value my time. It's just his way of showing disrespect for my hard work. If I were more important to him, would he bother calling in the middle of the night? Probably not. But does he care enough to call me out of the blue? He must have something on his mind, but since I don't know what it is, it must be personal. Maybe he has a problem with how I handled a case last week. Whatever it is, I can bet it's because I messed up somehow. I've been working so much overtime lately; maybe he thinks I need some extra rest. Still, it feels like he's trying to get under my skin. His late-night calls make me question everything, especially when it happens right after a stressful day. I guess it's just part of being a doctor, but honestly, I wish he didn't call so late. It makes me feel like I'm overworked and underappreciated.
